if you dont know if something is jazz when listening to it, then how do you know something is jazz when you are performing it? (referring to your jazz page)

the reason that page is labeled jazz is because it's just opening up the book to a tune, picking a tempo (perhaps not even the original tempo!) and jamming through it with the boys. usually playing the head once through, and then improvising over the form. this activity has been called jazz. jazz can mean many different things but that's one of the things it has meant, and the title of that page is a reference to those types of sessions. as a twist, when it is used in that context it usually refers to a different instrumentation than i'm using, and it is a live jam between 4 different people. whereas i'm doing it all myself. but the activity is very much the same. especially considering that the first several dozen tunes i did were sight read from the Real Book, which has been a staple of these types of sessions

so you've started out doing writing, and then turned that into videos/songs wich you've uploaded.but why did you start out with the short videos?was it to keep order or because it was easier?

it's always easier to start small. i hear from people every day saying they can't figure out how to follow through on a large project. the answer is to do shorter projects for a while. they get done, and you learn more and more tricks, really quickly. it's like building a house. you're never gonna build a large house by yourself on the first try

So I'll be volunteering at a youth education center this summer. My boss was like, "I like for each volunteer to develop some programming for the students based on something you know well and love." I responded that I could teach music/music theory to the kids. Then she was like, "Awesome. That'll be a great experience for them. But what's the practical use of music theory? Like in actual school." And... I did not know what she meant or how to answer. I just murmured something about rhythm and math or something. So my question: How would you answer that? Is music theory a good thing for non-musicians to just learn?

music theory can be any way you have of understanding the music you are playing. the theory might be totally different depending on which music your playing. i'm not sure if that answers your question

Do you ever think about how bacteria are just made of chemistry and reactions but like really smart chemistry that doesn't have to just bump into other molecules randomly?So some weird stuff happened first that no one really knows (maybe it was like an enzyme molecule thing that catalysed a reaction in which another enzyme molecule is made so the more of the substrate it gets to go via it's reaction pathway, the more enzyme there is and then the more it can get substrate and then..)  and then one day you suddenly have these bacteria things that are basically mini robots that are programmed to drive to things they can react with - kitted out with state of the art reaction driving and maximising equipment. But they don't choose where they go they just get dragged around by chemotaxis.But then chemotaxis gets really really complicated and the mini robots team up into little groups of robots (by accident) to make eukaryotes and these basically become ultra amazing jellyfish robots and it gets kinda hard to start to see where they're just getting dragged around by chemotaxis and where they're making decisions i mean could you call an insect's behaviour decisions? Then some filler and thanks to some handy processes like evolution and natural selection we get the next gen. supercomputer chemistry that can think and work with other supercomputers to keep doing what it's always done without ever really realising it. Because there was no such thing as realising something. And then the more they work together the smarter they get and eventually the chemistry based supercomputers learn what chemistry is. And then it's weird because the chemical system on a passive level is incredible at chemistry with a super fine tuned system but actively doesn't even understand what chemistry is and is kind of shit at it.  So we're kind of chemistry doing chemistry because it means it doesn't have to deal with random stuff on an even better level and it beats entropy even more extravagantly than it did before - using the passive system, that took billions of years to develop by chance, to move individual atoms and make structures like laptops and abstract  structu res like music that are too statistically unlikely and should never exist but if you go the long way around to making them by starting with bacteria they do.So I'm just a chemical system that become sentient? Is that supposed to mean something? I guess you could even say chemistry had to be made too from more fundamental stuff. Will AI be like the next level after us? cos it's still chemistry just kinda like it realised what it was and instead of waiting for evolution built a better, faster, smarter vessel for itself. If it wants - if we want.So the universe went from having no purpose and just random stuff to having a purpose. Because we want things does that count as purpose?Idk kinda rambley.
i'm not sure, but once you figure out consciousness, it seems to be a runaway train from there. and there is no reason to turn back, and i don't think anyone ever has

hey bill, on "5.1.17  11:20 am" you answered a question concerning something called the "5 day schedule" and you talk about the year 2009 and how your creativity and productivity exploded. Can you fill me in on this, or link me something more in depth about it? it seems interesting what you talk about there how you had your mind blown by things and started writing much more

the (ref: http://billwurtz.com/schedule.png)5 day schedule was in early 2014 when i decided i was going to start making videos (or a song) 5 days a week, in order to catch up on all the songs i'd written, and also hopefully jumpstart the video making process. 2009 was generally the time that i started writing much more songs, because i realized that anything is possible and you can start anywhere. i also started recording them too (very important if you want them to actually exist) but not nearly as fast as i was writing, and i kept writing more and more as the years went by, and i didn't really catch up on recording until 2014. just kidding i never caught up

Whenever I try to write music, it's difficult for me to expand beyond a single musical idea and develop it into a larger song. Do you ever face this problem and if so, how do you work past it?

Hey, it's me, person watching your videos everyday. So, I'm wondering, why did you bring up the sultan of Oman living in Zanzibar? It's pretty funny but seems unrelated to everything else. One of my favourite things about the video is how you make history into an interrelated narrative in which everything mentioned is important. But the Sultan thing seems super random. Thanks!

there are hundreds, thousands of things that happened in world history, so needless to say it was an insane challenge to figure out what to include and what to cut, and a never ending impossible balancing act. to help stay upbeat and sane in this project, i found it important early on to keep a very light and free attitude about the whole thing. people are surely going to get on my case for 'not mentioning this' and 'not mentioning that,' you can't mention everything that ever happened in one video. so the only way to really keep my shit together was just remember that this is a crazy thing to attempt, so just keep it fun, and don't be afraid to include weird things on purpose, just as a reminder that this is supposed to be fun, to hopefully distract from the fact that it is impossible to actually mention everything. the oman jingle was written in an early draft, and then got cut along with a million other things, but i liked the jingle so much i brought it back. trying to keep the whole thing perfectly balanced with an equal amount of details everywhere is kind of like drawing a straight line in a hurricane. at some point you have to just accept that certain random things are going to have extra details. also once a bit is written and turns out good, it can be hard to let go of. other examples would include the chandragupta/seleucis elephant deal, the robespierre stuff, etc. i had a hundred years war bit that i liked so much i was so sad to cut it, but there was surely already way too much britain/france in the video, and the first thing people usually complain about in history videos is that there's too much europe. so i had to cut it

Let's say you were writing something in B-flat major. And at the beginning of one measure, you have a natural on an E-flat in the left hand. Would you also  write a natural on an E if there were one in the right hand in the same measure? Or do you assume that the natural applies to every E in that measure, not just the E that is one the same line/space as the first E?

ah, that is a good question. i'm sure everyone will chime in saying it's one way or the other, but from what i've seen, there is no clear answer. that's why it's good to use 'courtesy accidentals' which is when you put the accidental (that's the sharp/flat/natural symbol) in parentheses

Why is there no B# or Cb

there is. B# means C, and Cb means B. you might use B# if you are coming up a scale like F#, G#, A#, C, C#. but you can see if we use B# instead, it looks like F#, G#, A#, B#, C# it looks a little neater because we have 1 of each letter, instead of having no B and 2 C's and have to un-sharp and re-sharp the C. same thing the other way, if you are in Gb major, you might prefer to say Gb, Ab, Bb, Cb, Db neatly so you use all the letters in a row, instead of having to un-flat and re-flat the B by going Gb, Ab, Bb, Bnatural, Db. if you are writing on the staff, the advantage of keeping it scalar become even more clear. i hope that makes sense

I love making funky chords on the piano and such but I also wanna know what people are talking about when they add a seventh

if you have a c major chord (c, e, g) adding a major 7th note means adding B, and adding a flat seventh means adding Bb. it's like if you go up a C scale (c,d,e,f,g etc) and count 1,2,3,4,5 etc, it's the 7th note. which is either B or Bb depending on what mood you're in
or sustain a chord

sustaining a chord just means holding it down. like if you play a chord and don't let go. pianos also have a pedal for this, so you can play the chord and let go but if you are holding the 'sustain pedal' the chord will stay on until you lift the pedal. very handy

I want to make a living off of creating abstract art, dance, poetry, and possibly own music later on (I don't currently have the resources to record good audio.) and posting it on the internet. Do you think this is feasible? I would like to try either way, but I feel like it would be good to know what you think. Should I have a back up plan?

if you really want to make the kind of material you want to make, you will need to find a separate way to earn a living. it might be handy to try to use your special skills as an advantage in finding a job, but if you really want to be free to make the kind of material you want, you are going to want to eliminate the immediate pressure to have it earn money. otherwise you will be forced to completely change what you do in order to follow the money, and it might cause you to be mad at the world. so i recommend getting any kind of work you can, and then in the remaining time work toward exactly where you want to go

what part of hotewig took the most research/time to tl;dr down for us plebs? (whether that was learning about it or deciding to keep it in or out of the script). thanks again for condensing 11 months into 20 minutes

i'm not sure, but over the summer is when the research/writing happened. from about 2000bc to 1500ad i was going in 500 year blocks. i would just learn everything i could for every region, and write it all down, and then i had to basically just bang my head into a wall trying to get it to fit together. like a puzzle, and it had to make sense and it had to be interesting and it had to also be short. oh and after 2 months writing i reached the end but it was 20min45sec and still not 'good' enough, so during phase 2 (planning out the video) i actually ended up doing a lot of re-writes mainly in the second half, to basically make everything even simpler and shorter. it was a real nightmare to condense all that down. i was pretty much hallucinating all the hateful "you left this out" comments, in advance. but there was nothing i could do, i had to move forward

How did you write New Canaan? I found it really relatable while I was in the middle of relationship shit, and I always thought I sounded to me like a bit of a Mumford and Sons song. What influences were going on there?

i wrote it on paper, during a train ride from grand central station to new canaan, on may 15, 2009. i also worked on it on the patio outside starbucks next to the train station in new canaan, and probably worked on it a bit more while waiting for the train back. this is the original chart ((ref: http://billwurtz.com/newcanaan-p1.jpg">page 1 and <a href="http://billwurtz.com/newcanaan-p2.jpg)page 2). then sometime during all the writing/finishing sessions in 2012/2013 it got fixed up and re-worked a bit, mostly in the second half, to generally make it a stronger song, but still reflecting the original story, even adding some details that were not originally mentioned but were still true, such as the license plate colors

okay, here's the situation. i am trying to listen to 1,000 albums of music this year. i am on track so far. i also want to release five album/ep's and i have each one planned. i am less on track with that, but it still seems feasible. at least, it was until today.today my piano teacher said I should be doing three hours of practice per day, and currently he has five jazz tunes (including one i have to transcribe) for me that I need to know inside out in a month, for an assessment. this would of course be doable and appropriately challenging under normal circumstances, but there is already so much going on, and i don't want to give up any of it.I'm already doing all but the bare minimum of schoolwork i am not passionate about (english, maths), and I don't play computer games or watch TV, but it just seems like there are not enough hours in the day.what is the best way to manage my time so that i can work on Multiple Projects even more swiftly and efficiently than I already am?

i'm not sure why you need someone else to tell you to transcribe tunes. can't you just decide on your own which tunes to transcribe? better yet, if you already have it on your agenda to listen to albums, why not just transcribe the albums you are listening to instead? also if it is on your agenda to make multiple albums, that is valuable real life musical experience. i don't see why you need to 'practice' for so many hours outside of that. if the piano teacher you mentioned is not willing to work congruently with your already established agenda, then i think those 2 agendas will come into conflict, as you have surely noticed

i get this thing where i try recording a song (whilst writing it) but i keep just listening to the part i made because i don't know how i should move forward. and i'll listen to it up to the point at that i don't like it anymore. any thoughts and/or tips for moving forward?

after experimenting both ways, i firmly believe that i can get much better results if i finish writing the song entirely before recording it. not micro-managing all the instruments choices and parts, but just the melody/chords and other core details, and most importantly the entire road map, beginning to end. do not leave any sections in question. in the studio you are free to have much more fun with sound choices etc if you don't have to worry about where the song goes next, if that's already planned out. this is just in my experience. some people thrive on writing in the studio. i have tried both ways and nowadays i firmly believe that what works best for me is to write to the end first, before even touching the recording.

why is it that an ensemble with many instruments in the high range can often sound great, but having more than one bass player is often disastrous?

the harmonic series is really like a tree. the branches get smaller as they go up, so there can be more of them. but 2 trunks would really never work. play 3rds on a piano starting from around middle C, and get lower and lower. you will hear them stop working at a certain point. this will be about 1 octave above the point where 5ths would stop working, and it would be about 2 octaves above the point where single notes stop working, which is usually the end of the instrument (like around low A on piano, or in my opinion B or C) i've found that the harmonic series actually illustrates this exactly. you'll see thirds appear 2 octaves above the source note. so in otherwords if you play thirds in a certain range, the amount of 'mess' it makes is equal to the amount of 'mess' it would make if you played 5ths an octave below that. or a single note 2 octaves below. that's why heavy guitar riffs often use 5ths, and the bass usually plays the same thing 1 octave below, but in a single note. if you try to play 5ths there it just sounds like an earthquake. another interesting way of illustrating this is if you put distortion on and play 5ths, it often sounds exactly like a single note, 1 octave down. it even works if you play 4ths with distortion. it often sounds like a single note 2 octaves below the highest note. again agreeing with the harmonic series that your 2 notes are a part of

I only ask because I started doing something similar a year ago and I've thought that for all of it. Is there any advice you can give other than "wait until you can't take it any longer"?

there are plenty of things you can do, and try. i was never totally frozen, but almost everything i did felt like some kind of test or learning experiment. also did a lot of analysis, and just a lot of listening to music and watching things as well, just taking it all in and pretty much getting my mind blown all the time, and learning new things, which didn't help stop my own ideas and goals from constantly exploding bigger and broader. you might argue that 2009 was when i said 'i can't take it anymore' and started writing like crazy. but it was all writing and almost no recording. then i gradually inched my way into recording in about 2010, but then started writing 10 times more. basically i ended up leading myself into a place where i felt like i had already done centuries worth of work, but yet none of it was finalized or realized. there were many different times where you might say it 'all started' but each one was just another step. i'm not sure if that answers your question

B, C#, G, F# are really the notes that we're working with here. also A could be buried in there somewhere but with the harmonica on A# you can't tell. and D# in the bass of course. sounds like a pretty standard D#aug7 (in the key of G#min) with all the usual suspects that you would find in a stevie sort of world
